Article.ArticleTitle: Suppressing Organic Bromine but Promoting Bromate: Is the Ultraviolet/Ozone Process a Double-Edged Sword for the Toxicity of Wastewater to Mammalian Cells?

AbstractText: Brominated byproducts and toxicity generation are critical issues for ozone application to wastewater containing bromide. This study demonstrated that ultraviolet/ozone (UV/O<sub>3</sub>, 100 mJ/cm<sup>2</sup>, 1 mg-O<sub>3</sub>/mg-DOC) reduced the cytotoxicity of wastewater from 14.2 mg of pentol/L produced by ozonation to 4.3 mg of pentol/L (1 mg/L bromide, pH 7.0). The genotoxicity was also reduced from 1.65 to 0.17 μg-4-NQO/L by UV/O<sub>3</sub>. Compared with that of O<sub>3</sub> alone, adsorbable organic bromine was reduced from 25.8 to 5.3 μg/L by UV/O<sub>3</sub>, but bromate increased from 32.9 to 71.4 μg/L. The UV/O<sub>3</sub> process enhanced the removal of pre-existing precursors (highly unsaturated and phenolic compounds and poly aromatic hydrocarbons), while new precursors were generated, yet the combined effect of UV/O<sub>3</sub> on precursors did not result in a significant change in toxicity. Instead, UV radiation inhibited HOBr concentration through both rapid O<sub>3</sub> decomposition to reduce HOBr production and decomposition of the formed HOBr, thus suppressing the AOBr formation. However, the hydroxyl radical-dominated pathway in UV/O<sub>3</sub> led to a significant increase of bromate. Considering both organic bromine and bromate, the UV/O<sub>3</sub> process effectively controlled both cytotoxicity and genotoxicity of wastewater to mammalian cells, even though an emphasis should be also placed on managing elevated bromate. Futhermore, other end points are needed to evaluate the toxicity outcomes of the UV/O<sub>3</sub> process.
